relation: configure terminal Example: Device# configure terminal
snmp-server tftp-server-list number Example: Device(config)# snmp-server tftp-server-list 12
Enables privileged EXEC mode. Enter your password if prompted.
Limits the number of TFTP servers used for configuration file copies via SNMP to the servers in an access list.
Exits global configuration mode and returns to privileged EXEC mode.
pageTitle: SNMP Configuration Guide, Cisco IOS XE Release 3S - Configuring SNMP Support [Support] - Cisco
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {71198=The SNMP manager is a system that controls and monitors the activities of network hosts using SNMP. The most common managing system is a network management system (NMS). The term NMS can be applied either to a dedicated device used for network management or to the applications used on such a device. Several network management applications are available for use with SNMP and range from simple command line interface applications to applications such as the CiscoWorks2000 products that use GUIs., 68686=A MIB is a virtual information storage area for network management information and consists of collections of managed objects. Within a MIB are collections of related objects defined in MIB modules. MIB modules are written in the SNMP MIB module language, as defined in STD 58, RFC 2578, RFC 2579, and RFC 2580 (see the "MIBs and RFCs" topic in the "Simple Network Management Protocol" module for an explanation of RFCs and Standard documents). Individual MIB modules are also referred to as MIBs; for example, the Interfaces Group MIB (IF-MIB) is a MIB module within the MIB on your system., 23044=The Circuit Interface Identification Persistence for SNMP feature was introduced with the CSCds67851. The Circuit Interface MIB (CISCO-CIRCUIT-INTERFACE-MIB) provides a MIB object (cciDescr) that can be used to identify individual circuit-based interfaces for SNMP monitoring. The Cisco Circuit Interface Identification MIB was introduced in CSCdp81924., 42416=SNMPv3 supports RFCs 1901 to 1908, 2104, 2206, 2213, 2214, and 2271 to 2275. For additional information about SNMPv3, see RFC 2570, Introduction to Version 3 of the Internet-standard Network Management Framework (this is not a standards document)., 53509=The Cisco implementation of SNMP uses the definitions of MIB II variables described in RFC 1213 and definitions of SNMP traps described in RFC 1215., 10995=You can globally enable or disable authenticationFailure, linkUp, linkDown, warmStart, and coldStart traps or informs individually. (These traps constitute the "generic traps" defined in RFC 1157.) Note that linkUp and linkDown notifications are enabled by default on specific interfaces but will not be sent unless they are enabled globally., 106165=2.    setany -v2c $ADDRESS private mteTriggerValueID.4.106.111.104.110.1 -d 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.10}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {590931=RFC 1908, 323564=Device(config)# snmp-server engineID remote 172.16.20.3 vrf traps-vrf, 588913=RFC 1215, 591844=RFC 2206, 168618=Device(config)# snmp-server engineID remote 172.16.20.3 80000009030000B064EFE100, 560524=The following example shows how to permit SNMP access to all objects with read-only permission using the community string named public. The router will also send ISDN traps to the hosts 172.16.1.111 and 172.16.1.33 using SNMPv1 and to the host 172.16.1.27 using SNMPv2c. The community string named public is sent with the traps., 588317=RFC 1213, 592326=RFC 2213, 589903=RFC 1905, 587409=RFC 1098, 570429=In the following example, the VRF named "traps-vrf" is configured for the remote server 172.16.20.3:, 168814=Specifies the SNMP engine ID and configures the VRF name traps-vrf for SNMP communications with the remote device at 172.16.20.3., 51614=Device(config)# snmp-server host 172.16.1.27 version 2c public, 593769=RFC 2271, 594906=RFC 2578, 596259=RFC 2981, 594289=RFC 2570, 586570=RFC 1067, 81802=Device(config)# snmp-server engineID remote 172.12.15.4 udp-port 120 1a2833c0129a, 590486=RFC 1906, 592848=RFC 2214, 593475=RFC 2233, 587863=RFC 1157, 205196=Enables RFC 1157 generic traps., 606396=The Event MIB feature was implemented on the Cisco ASR 1000 series routers., 591385=RFC 2104, 615173=The SNMP Manager feature was implemented on the Cisco ASR 1000 series routers., 595422=RFC 2579, 589477=RFC 1901, 587019=RFC 1091, 595839=RFC 2580}
textBeforeTable: DETAILED STEPS 4.   exit 3.    snmp-server tftp-server-list number 2.    configure terminal 1.    enable SUMMARY STEPS Perform this task to limit the number of TFTP servers. You can limit the number of TFTP servers used for saving and loading configuration files via SNMP by using an access list. Limiting the use of TFTP servers in this way conserves system resources and centralizes the operation for manageability. Limiting the Number of TFTP Servers Used via SNMP Exits global configuration mode and returns to privileged EXEC mode.   Device(config)# exit   Example: exit Step 4 Establishes the maximum packet size.   Device(config)# snmp-server packetsize 512   Example:
textAfterTable: Troubleshooting Tips Troubleshooting Tips To monitor SNMP trap activity in real time for the purposes of troubleshooting, use the SNMP debug commands, including the debug snmp packet EXEC command. For documentation of SNMP debug commands, see the Cisco IOS Debug Command Reference. Disabling the SNMP Agent SUMMARY STEPS 1.    enable 2.    configure terminal 3.    no snmp-server 4.   end DETAILED STEPS   Command or Action Purpose Step 1 enable Example: Device> enable   Enables privileged EXEC mode.
